cards.title: Like a prayer / South London's African churches

item.title: Like a prayer: south London's African churches
item.trailText: Southwark is home to 240 African christianity churches - the largest concentration outside of Africa. The photographer Chloe Dewe Matthews captured a community bringing
item.standFirst:
Southwark is home to 240 African churches, the largest concentration outside Africa. The buildings are often hidden on nondescript high streets, or in bleak industrial complexes – in stark contrast to the brightly coloured outfits of the congregants, captured here by photographer Chloe Dewe Matthews

  • Congregation is at Bosse & Baum gallery in Peckham until 21 June

displayImages.caption:
Study for Congregation #1
This is my poster shot, taken in House of Praise on Camberwell Road. It was a thanksgiving service and also one of the ladies’ birthdays. Everyone was dressed up and really going for it. It was just beautiful and I feel the photograph really captures the sea of colours and fabrics. It was very abstract and joyful.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Study for Congregation #1
This is my poster shot, taken in House of Praise on Camberwell Road. It was a thanksgiving service and also one of the ladies’ birthdays. Everyone was dressed up and really going for it. It was just beautiful and I feel the photograph really captures the sea of colours and fabrics. It was very abstract and joyful.

displayImages.caption:
A woman leaves the House of Praise, a converted bingo hall in Camberwell
When the Tate first commissioned me to make a body of work about Southwark, I had no idea that the borough had the highest density of African Christianity outside Africa. I came across a study by Roehampton University which counted 240 African churches in the area, which is remarkable.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
A woman leaves the House of Praise, a converted bingo hall in Camberwell
When the Tate first commissioned me to make a body of work about Southwark, I had no idea that the borough had the highest density of African Christianity outside Africa. I came across a study by Roehampton University which counted 240 African churches in the area, which is remarkable.

displayImages.caption:
Peckham Road bus stop
A lot of people don’t live nearby. Many people here stay loyal to particular pastors, or to a certain area or a certain country that their lineage is from. A lot of people would travel for an hour to get to the churches and then the service itself might be two or three hours, so the process was very long.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Peckham Road bus stop
A lot of people don’t live nearby. Many people here stay loyal to particular pastors, or to a certain area or a certain country that their lineage is from. A lot of people would travel for an hour to get to the churches and then the service itself might be two or three hours, so the process was very long.

displayImages.caption:
The Redeemed Christian Church of God: Holy Ghost Zone
I’ve always noticed these churches and their evocative names, which stand out in the ordinariness of London streets. While I was taking this shot of “Holy Ghost Zone”, someone came up to me and said, “People always take photos of this church”. The name is so striking.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
The Redeemed Christian Church of God: Holy Ghost Zone
I’ve always noticed these churches and their evocative names, which stand out in the ordinariness of London streets. While I was taking this shot of “Holy Ghost Zone”, someone came up to me and said, “People always take photos of this church”. The name is so striking.

displayImages.caption:
Interior #2 Liberty House
This is one of my favourite shots. I think it works as a still-life, suggesting human activity and the creative use of this industrial space. I spent a lot of time at Liberty House, and felt particularly connected to the congregation there.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Interior #2 Liberty House
This is one of my favourite shots. I think it works as a still-life, suggesting human activity and the creative use of this industrial space. I spent a lot of time at Liberty House, and felt particularly connected to the congregation there.

displayImages.caption:
New Covenant Church
The 1960s facade of this church has a straightforward visual appeal. These neutral, former industrial spaces lend themselves well to large groups and energetic worship.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
New Covenant Church
The 1960s facade of this church has a straightforward visual appeal. These neutral, former industrial spaces lend themselves well to large groups and energetic worship.

displayImages.caption: Two church-goers outside Freedom Centre International, Peckham
displayImages.cleanCaption: Two church-goers outside Freedom Centre International, Peckham

displayImages.caption:
Mountain of Fire and Miracles Ministries: Camberwell branch
There’s a large density of churches on Walworth Road. Here you can see two churches next door to each other. The sign says, ‘Inviting you to banquet’, and quite often there are people eating towards the end of church services. People will bring in their own food or there’ll be someone selling bits and pieces with a microwave. Photograph: Chloe Dewe Mathews/Chloe Dewe Mathews
displayImages.altText: Mountain of Fire and Miracles Ministries: Camberwell Branch  There’s a large density of churches on Walworth Road. Here you can actually see there’s two churches next door to each other. The sign says “Inviting You To Banquet” and quite often there are people eating towards the end of church services. People will bring in their own food or there’ll be someone selling bits and piece with a microwave.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Mountain of Fire and Miracles Ministries: Camberwell branch
There’s a large density of churches on Walworth Road. Here you can see two churches next door to each other. The sign says, ‘Inviting you to banquet’, and quite often there are people eating towards the end of church services. People will bring in their own food or there’ll be someone selling bits and pieces with a microwave.
displayImages.cleanCredit: Photograph: Chloe Dewe Mathews/Chloe Dewe Mathews

displayImages.caption: A prophetess arriving at Cherubim and Seraphim, Copeland Park industrial estate, Peckham
displayImages.cleanCaption: A prophetess arriving at Cherubim and Seraphim, Copeland Park industrial estate, Peckham

displayImages.caption:
Copeland Park industrial estate
People feel that Peckham is being gentrified and that artists in an area can represent the first phase of that, but I felt it was important to show the work in the place where I made it.

Interview by Charlie Brinkhurst Cuff
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Copeland Park industrial estate
People feel that Peckham is being gentrified and that artists in an area can represent the first phase of that, but I felt it was important to show the work in the place where I made it.

Interview by Charlie Brinkhurst Cuff

It was just beautiful and I feel the photograph really captures the sea of colours and fabrics. It was very abstract and joyful.

cards.title: The Arab Spring failed women – we need a sexual revolution in the Middle East
cards.rawTitle: The Arab Spring failed women – we need a sexual revolution in the Middle East

item.title: We need a sexual revolution in the Middle East
item.trailText: Let's face it, the Arab Spring failed women – they are no closer to liberation than before the uprisings, argues Mona Eltahawy
item.standFirst: 'Let's face it, the Arab Spring failed women. They are no closer to liberation than before the uprisings.' Mona Eltahawy, who was beaten and sexually assaulted by Egyptian riot police in 2011, argues that feminism is a vital movement wherever you are – both 'over here' and 'over there'
item.byline: Mona Eltahawy, Leah Green, Maya Wolfe-Robinson and Caterina Monzani

stillImage.caption: MonaHodingPic Photograph: Mosa'ab Elshamy/Moment Editorial Photograph: Mosa'ab Elshamy/Moment Editorial

displayImages.caption: MonaHodingPic Photograph: Mosa'ab Elshamy/Moment Editorial Photograph: Mosa'ab Elshamy/Moment Editorial

cards.title: Border crossing / Syrian refugees enter Turkey

item.title: Syrian refugees at the Turkish border
item.trailText: People fleeing the civil war in Syria continue to stream into Turkey from Tal Abyad, a town at the border crossing near Akçakale
item.standFirst: People fleeing the civil war in Syria continue to stream into Turkey from Tal Abyad, a town at the border crossing near Akçakale. More than 320,000 people – including more than 60,000 civilian adults and over 7,000 children – are thought to have been killed in the conflict, according to the UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights

displayImages.caption: Turkish military use water cannon to stop Syrian refugees as they wait behind border fences  Photograph: Osman Orsal/Reuters

cards.title: 40-second fix / Can China save the world's climate?
cards.rawTitle: Can China save the world's climate?

item.title: Can China fix the world's climate?
item.trailText: China is the biggest polluter in the world and burns more coal than anywhere else. But are the Chinese about to turn the climate corner?
item.standFirst: China is the biggest polluter in the world and burns more coal than anywhere else. The country's swelling middle class and enormous population could produce colossal emissions well into the future, locking the world into a dangerous pattern of greenhouse warming. But are the Chinese about to turn the climate corner?
item.byline: Scriberia, Karl Mathiesen, Nabeelah Shabbir, Pascal Wyse and Paul Boyd

stillImage.caption: 620x372 trailpic for Can China fix the climate? 40 Second Climate Fix - video Photograph: guardian.co.uk
stillImage.altText: 620x372 trailpic for Can China fix the climate? 40 Second Climate Fix - video
stillImage.cleanCaption: 620x372 trailpic for Can China fix the climate? 40 Second Climate Fix - video

item.title: Homes with pools
item.trailText: As summer approaches our thoughts turn to the pleasure of a cool dip. Here are some properties you won’t want to leave
item.standFirst: As summer approaches our thoughts turn to the pleasure of a cool dip. Here are some properties you won’t want to leave

displayImages.caption:
Home: Invergowrie, near Dundee, Perth and Kinross
Hardy blood is a prerequisite to make the most of this pool during a Scottish summer, for all that it’s heated. The house was built for author Rosamunde Pilcher who wanted to echo the architecture of her native Cornwall. It’s built for an outdoor lifestyle with tennis court, paddock, stables and orchard. But there’s wide scope when Arctic blasts compel you inside given the three receptions, seven bedrooms and attics. The planners are happy for you to build a house in the paddock. Offers above £895,000.
CKD Galbraith, 01334 659 980
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Home: Invergowrie, near Dundee, Perth and Kinross
Hardy blood is a prerequisite to make the most of this pool during a Scottish summer, for all that it’s heated. The house was built for author Rosamunde Pilcher who wanted to echo the architecture of her native Cornwall. It’s built for an outdoor lifestyle with tennis court, paddock, stables and orchard. But there’s wide scope when Arctic blasts compel you inside given the three receptions, seven bedrooms and attics. The planners are happy for you to build a house in the paddock. Offers above £895,000.
CKD Galbraith, 01334 659 980

displayImages.caption:
Home: Warehaus, London E8
Careful what you wear when cleaving through the waters, for this glass-bottomed roof-top pool doubles as the atrium roof of this new block. The apartments, modelled on a 1930s warehouse, have heated walls, extra height concrete ceilings and a balcony. The 24-hour concierge will stow your supermarket deliveries in a refrigerated store until you get home from work. From £535,000 for one bedroom.
Union Developments, 0800 043 2523
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Home: Warehaus, London E8
Careful what you wear when cleaving through the waters, for this glass-bottomed roof-top pool doubles as the atrium roof of this new block. The apartments, modelled on a 1930s warehouse, have heated walls, extra height concrete ceilings and a balcony. The 24-hour concierge will stow your supermarket deliveries in a refrigerated store until you get home from work. From £535,000 for one bedroom.
Union Developments, 0800 043 2523

displayImages.caption:
Away: Begur, Costa Brava, Spain
The glass walled living area sits side by side with the infinity pool and the four en suite bedrooms overlook the wider blue of the sea. There’s a self-contained guest apartment and, since when you’re rich enough for the £1.8m price tag, all exertion should be for pleasure only, a lift to take you upstairs to bed.
Lucas Fox, +34 933 562 989
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Away: Begur, Costa Brava, Spain
The glass walled living area sits side by side with the infinity pool and the four en suite bedrooms overlook the wider blue of the sea. There’s a self-contained guest apartment and, since when you’re rich enough for the £1.8m price tag, all exertion should be for pleasure only, a lift to take you upstairs to bed.
Lucas Fox, +34 933 562 989

displayImages.caption:
Away: Little Compton, Rhode Island, US
When you tire of this swirl of swimming pool you are entitled to frolic in the nearby lake owned by the Quicksand Pond Association or swim from a sandy beach in this seaside town. The £582,000 air-conditioned house has four bedrooms with room for expansion above the master suite, polished wooden floors and 5.35 acres of leafy gardens.
Lila Delman Real Estate, +1 401 848 2101
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Away: Little Compton, Rhode Island, US
When you tire of this swirl of swimming pool you are entitled to frolic in the nearby lake owned by the Quicksand Pond Association or swim from a sandy beach in this seaside town. The £582,000 air-conditioned house has four bedrooms with room for expansion above the master suite, polished wooden floors and 5.35 acres of leafy gardens.
Lila Delman Real Estate, +1 401 848 2101

displayImages.caption:
Away: Montedinove, Marche, Italy
This is the restored watchtower of a medieval castle and from your Li-Lo in the pool you can survey miles of wild mountainscape. French doors open the kitchen and two receptions on to a courtyard above the panorama and there’s a terrace among three of the bedrooms on the first floor. There’s an annexe, yet to be restored and a private orchard of olive trees. On the market for £585,440.
Italian Luxury Asset, +39 349 232 1597
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Away: Montedinove, Marche, Italy

Away: Montedinove, Marche, Italy
This is the restored watchtower of a medieval castle and from your Li-Lo in the pool you can survey miles of wild mountainscape. French doors open the kitchen and two receptions on to a courtyard above the panorama and there’s a terrace among three of the bedrooms on the first floor. There’s an annexe, yet to be restored and a private orchard of olive trees. On the market for £585,440.
Italian Luxury Asset, +39 349 232 1597

cards.title: Joshua Oppenheimer on The Look of Silence / It's a memoriam for the lives that are broken
cards.rawTitle: It's a memoriam for the lives that are broken

item.title: Joshua Oppenheimer on The Look of Silence: 'It's a memoriam for the lives that are broken' – video interview
item.trailText: The director of the documentary on Indonesia's mass killings on the ruthless profiteering of American businesses and challenging the killers to face their guilt
item.standFirst: Joshua Oppenheimer, the director of The Look of Silence, explains how his second documentary on the mass killings in 1960s Indonesia relates to the ruthless profiteering of American businesses and how the film challenges the killers to face their guilt. The Look of Silence is released in the UK on Friday 12 June

cards.title: Is this mountain hare really scurrying across an avalanche?
cards.rawTitle: Is this mountain hare really scurrying across an avalanche?

item.title: Is this mountain hare really scurrying across an avalanche?
item.trailText: A snowboarding video filmed by Helipro in the Kamchatka peninsula, Russia, appears to show a mountain hare evading an avalanche ... but is it real?
item.standFirst: A snowboarding video filmed by Helipro in the Kamchatka peninsula, Russia, appears to show a mountain hare evading an avalanche by hopping and scrambling over the tumbling snow until it is able to jump to safety. The footage ends before we see the mountain hare scampering off. Is this real or is it a fake, what do you think?
